## 1.  Full citation and context  

| Item | Details |
|------|---------|
| **Speaker** | Alexander Hamilton Stephens (1812‑1883), former U.S. Congressman, Governor of Georgia (1853‑1857), and Vice‑President of the Confederacy (1861‑1865). |

| **Publication** | Printed the same day in the *Richmond Enquirer* (Richmond, Va.) and later re‑printed in the *Southern Historical Society Papers* (vol. 3, 1886). The text is also included in the *Collected Works of Alexander H. Stephens* (University of Georgia Press, 1994). |
| **Why it matters** | Stephens was the second‑most senior official in the Confederate government and the speech was intended as a public justification of the new nation’s founding principles. It was not a private letter or a post‑war recollection; it was a contemporaneous, official statement. |

---

## 2.  Key excerpts (the most frequently quoted passages)

> **“Our new constitution is founded upon… the great truth that the negro is not equal to the white man; that slavery… is his natural and normal condition.”**  
> — *Cornerstone Speech*, paragraph 4.

> **“The negro is a human being, but he is not a man in the full sense of the word, and his destiny is to be the servant of the white man.”**  
> — *Cornerstone Speech*, paragraph 5.

> **“This is the cornerstone of the new government. It is the ‘first principle of the Confederacy.’ …It is the great truth that the ‘black’ is a race of people, and that they are not the peers of the ‘white’ race, but are in a lower, subordinate condition.”**  
> — *Cornerhood Speech*, paragraph 6.

> **“The Constitution of the United States… is a ‘compact’ between the states, … but it is a compact that was made *without* regard to the ‘natural’ condition of the African race, and therefore the Southern people are justified in establishing a separate government that recognises this ‘natural’ order.”**  
> — *Cornerstone Speech*, paragraph 9.

> **“The Constitution of the Confederate States… expressly protects the institution of slavery, and it is the duty of every citizen, and indeed of every state, to defend it against all attempts at interference, whether from the North or from any other quarter.”**  
> — *Cornerstone Speech*, closing paragraph.
